body: Can you try the `dev` branch?

Sorry I wrote that before looking closely at your code... Yes `_request` won't work.

The empty ```local'`` and `$global` should work soon. I have to look more into `pause`.

But other than the empty macros, these seem kinda esoteric.

I can't do the dev branch because I get:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/runpy.py", line 183, in _run_module_as_main
    mod_name, mod_spec, code = _get_module_details(mod_name, _Error)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/runpy.py", line 109, in _get_module_details
    __import__(pkg_name)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/stata_kernel/__init__.py", line 5, in <module>
    from .kernel import StataKernel
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/stata_kernel/kernel.py", line 7, in <module>
    from .completions import CompletionsManager
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'stata_kernel.completions'
```

As of 24 minutes ago [that should be fixed](https://github.com/kylebarron/stata_kernel/blob/dev/stata_kernel/completions.py), though there's now a new bug because I changed from str to Pathlib for paths. (I had forgotten it was in 3.5 and not just 3.6)
Cool beans. It still gets tripped, tho. Btw is the code structure in `dev` stable? I'm meaning to give mata support another go.
Actually ``` `local'``` and `$global` might be hard to fix. Because there's no way for me to know that it's invalid input.

Can you give me an example where using

```
re.compile(r'\r\n\. \Z', flags=re.MULTILINE)
```

to detect the end of Stata output fails? At a glance that would fix:

```
`local'
$global
qui do file
```

Then `r' \. \Z'` seems to capture the first two cases; it can print something like "interactive output is not supported" or "incomplete input; aborting execution" or similar. The docstring notes "false positives" but I don't really know how to generate them.

This just happened to me accidentally: `!` enters a bash prompt for me, and that definitely trips up `expect`. I can technically use bash inside stata inside bash inside stata... While it's tempting to redirect "!" and "shell" through python, it won't resolve globals and locals correctly. Maybe pipe the statement through `disp` and then use `subprocess`?

`\Z`, like `$` in the regex would do nothing:
https://pexpect.readthedocs.io/en/stable/overview.html#find-the-end-of-line-cr-lf-conventions

> Pexpect reads from the child one character at a time

I'm not entirely sure how that makes sense. Since passing the compiled regex seems to work on my system, can you humor me and find an example where it fails so I can let it go as "what works for me is not cross platform"? If it's too much of a hassle let me know and I can let it go anyway.

Speaking of which, another one that trips it up for me:

```
mata printf("\r\n\r\n. ")
```

But does work with the regex I proposed.

Well pexpect reads the input characters as a stream. It doesn't know when it's at the end of the stream. 

However I'm a little confused with testing. I don't know why pexpect doesn't stop after either of the first two `\r\n\. `. Maybe I'll have to try this on Mac as well.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164633/44037702-f85876f4-9ee2-11e8-8663-3a42ca1e3c39.png)

The general idea is that the expect characters must not show up anywhere except as a prompt. If you do `di _n(2) ". "` that will mess up pexpect as well. But ideally this is the most peculiar regex least likely to show up as a result.

If interested you could see how pexpect deals with regex. I haven't looked into it closely.

https://github.com/pexpect/pexpect/blob/ab7d99a670794fc2b0365440340b899a346422da/pexpect/expect.py#L220-L306

> > Pexpect reads from the child one character at a time
>
> I'm not entirely sure how that makes sense. Since passing the compiled regex seems to work on my system, can you humor me and find an example where it fails so I can let it go as "what works for me is not cross platform"? If it's too much of a hassle let me know and I can let it go anyway.

From my understanding, it reads from the child `n` characters at a time, where `n` is the `searchwindowsize` option. If it's read `2n` characters and the regex matches, then it stops. I haven't looked into how it would use the `\Z`.

It seems that the number of characters read at a time are `maxread` as set in `spawn`; see [here](https://github.com/pexpect/pexpect/blob/ab7d99a670794fc2b0365440340b899a346422da/pexpect/pty_spawn.py). For example, if I start stata via `spawn` with `maxread = 1` then my regex gets messed up. 

However, in that case the current regex gets messed up as well, along with the above. It honestly seems impossible to do this adequately via regex. I mean, you could cheat and append something to the end of each command and ignore it later. Send `.StataKernelDone` or something like that. Not at all satisfying, but this is method is already probabilistic in nature....

If you set maxread to 1 the current regex gets messed up? Displaying some final text might be most helpful. 

Another thing to think about is how to make Stata stop on error inside a block. If you send a block from Jupyter Notebook, for example, that has `program test`, where `test` has already been defined, the entire program will be sent to Stata console, but the first line will error. So the following lines will be executed and not defined as a program.

It does with the example you were using.

Instead of displaying text, I reckon it's faster to just hack it by declaring an object. Though if it's just going to be at the end of whatever is executed such minor speed bumps shouldn't matter.

You _could_ create a do file and pass the output via `do tempfile.do`; you'd have to add a hook at the end of the file to loop through all the locals and `c_local` them up to the current environment. Executing via `do` will stop execution of the file by default.
I had considered using a do file, or at least giving the option of using a do file, originally, but I thought it would lose all the locals by default. What is `c_local`?
Also the example I gave was an example of what I thought _should_ stop pexpect early. I was surprised that it continued until the actual end of the line.

```
disp `hi'
program hi
c_local hi 1234
end
hi
disp `hi'
```

You van use the code I have for local completions to get all locals and then loop them up via `c_local`
You would use `c_local lvar: copy local lvar` to hedge against space trimming, etc.

:open_mouth: How do you find these things? There's no man page or help page.

It's so useful for debugging. Is there a way to do `c_local _all` or something at the beginning of a do file in order for all the locals to be left in the global environment?

That's how IPython works and I love it. If I'm debugging a for loop, I can do:
```py
for (a, b), c in tuples:
    break
```
and if I run that code, the value of `a`, `b`, and `c` in memory is the first element of `tuples`. It makes debugging so easy.
You should look into the oxymoronically named `help undocumented`

This hangs for me:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164633/44045211-d45261f8-9ef5-11e8-84e5-c07cb3c70b05.png)
Even after reading through `help undocumented` I _still_ can't find `_c_local`.

> This hangs for me:

You mean on the kernel? Yes, with the current regexes that would hang. You mean it hands with the experimental ones?
Yes. I didn't realize that would hang with the current regex. Is that because of the `qui`?
Yes.

But even with `qui`, there's two newlines and a `.` at the end?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164633/44045795-aa67c886-9ef7-11e8-82a0-ecde7b103eba.png)
